title: Welcome to College Chronicles
content:
Welcome to College Chronicles!

I'm Toba Banjo, and this is College Chronicles! Here you'll find a journal/blog type beat with my discoveries, recollections, and any wisdom I'm able to impart as I move forward with the admissions process. Hope you enjoy!

title: Road to ACT
snippet: I'm taking the ACT next week- some tips and things to know.
content:
It's hard to believe, but I'm taking the ACT next Saturday...

'Why aren't you doing the SAT?'

'Why now? Don't most people wait until senior year?'

'How can I prepare for the SAT?'

All valid questions which I have to imagine might come up. I'm going to wait to really get into them until *after* my scores are out, just to sort of back that I know what I'm talking about. For now, I can say this: Start studying now, ESPECIALLY if you're currently taking a precalculus class. From what I know, you've pretty much seen the full extent of possible content for either test, and would do well to begin preparing as soon as possible for a spring first run.

I'd say most people will be good with the SAT- if anyone cares for specifics, I'd be happy to get into more on why *I* chose the other path. Generally speaking, you'll want to take a full length practice test and begin to chip away at weaknesses. For specific tips, again, stay tuned for post-exam.

As for why you should do it now?

I feel like most people underestimate the sheer amount of preparatory tasks you're going to have to face in college applications. On top of essays, rec letters, and everything else, adding fall '25 tests to the pile is NOT a good idea.

My recommendation would be to take a test at some point between now and the end of the school year (the next SAT is in March). Then, if you don't like your score, take another one during the summer and hopefully perform just as well if not better.

I realize there might also be sophomores looking at the SAT advice from earlier- I think it's fair of me to assume that if you're already looking into testing in tenth grade, you're among the high achievers. Therefore, I take it you'll know to listen when I say HOLD OFF and wait until junior year. You have a significant amount of content to learn in Algebra II alone for the rest of the year, not even to talk of the precalc component. Plus, while English doesn't get that much more advanced, you'll pick up on a few things that should help you for the exam.

(And if you're in tenth grade and taking geometry as your highest math course, you REALLY should not be starting to prep, given that you're even further 'behind'.)

More than likely, you're just fine, you're on pace, and you're going to be okay. Keep up with everything asked of you for the rest of the school year- I think you can reasonably begin looking into things during rising junior summer if you'd like.

title: Beginning to Navigate College Selection
snippet: There are thousands of great schools in the United States. How do you narrow down your choices?
content:
Just days ago, I began my first dive into the world of college selection, and to my surprise, it's actually not been so bad. With a major in mind, a list of relevant criteria on hand, and the Fiske Guide by my side, I managed to cut down what was originally about 200 schools to just around 20.

So how did I do it?

It's actually surprisingly simple.

First of all, something to get out of the way: I'm well aware that the vast majority of college-hopefuls do not know what they're going to major in at this point in their high school career. Personally, I think that's just fine. I'm a bit different in the sense that, for as long as I've been able to put my fingers to the keyboard, I've been dead set on entering into computer science. Nothing's quite tickled my brain the same way since- as a result, I had the distinct advantage of being able to work my way down as opposed to building my way up. By that, I mean if you're unsure about what you intend to study, you might be better off doing a bit more research and making some choices yourself as opposed to starting by breaking up a T200 list like I did.

However, if you do have a major in mind, things get a lot easier. My first step was to open up US News and World Report; over there, I'd find their top CS schools and dump the majority into a Google Sheet. Then, the real fun began. I knew from the get go that it would be impossible to start looking into where I wanted to go if I had dozens and dozens of schools to choose from. That meant it was time to start contemplating what I really wanted in a college.

Other than some gut removals, the schools I decided to remove were largely due to falling short in one of the following categories: political differences, diversity, pricing, prestige, and population / proximity. I'll briefly go into each.

Political Differences

As far as these are concerned, I understand things aren't quite black and white when it comes to the electoral map. At the same time, there are some pretty blatant disagreements across political lines which I came to realize I'd rather avoid in dedicating four years of my life to a given school. I was able to solidly eliminate close to 40 or 50% of the list by looking at harsh per-state deviance from my broader views and beliefs.

Diversity

My feelings about this one could be due to my standing as an African-American, or not, I don't really know. Either way, I figured that, given the choice, I'd prefer to be surrounded by a mix of people from different backgrounds and cultures. Once again referring back to the US News & World Report, I began to add a diversity index to my spreadsheet. In essence, their system is a 0-1 scale with 0 meaning no diversity and 1 pointing to the most diverse. The highest ranking I saw across all US schools was 0.77; therefore, I thought it would make sense to cut any which fell below 0.6. This category probably had fewer cuts compared to some of the others, but helped to pretty easily rule out schools where I'd feel like an extreme outlier. The flip side could be weird, too; constantly surrounding myself with people just like me could get old pretty fast.

Pricing

I'm probably going to make a whole article about financial dealings closer to actually beginning applications; they're a whole beast of their own. Essentially, with help from the Fiske Guide's price and debt index, I raised a bit of an eyebrow to some colleges and cut off a few while still leaving my options open. I've barely begun looking into scholarships and financial aid, so this was another not-quite-huge contributor to narrowing down my list.

Prestige

This one was pretty straightforward. If you'll excuse me for sounding a bit full of it, I think my work ethic and accomplishments as a student lend themselves to reputable, meaningful education in the future. If any of the schools that were left fell out of or a little too close to the bottom T100 for CS, I cut them without too many regrets.

Population / Proximity

With all the other criteria out of the way, there were only about 40 schools left. My final requirement had to do with A) physical distance to home and B) the size of the student body. Unsurprisingly, most of the best CS schools are in or around New England, so I didn't have that much more work when it came to location. I was still able to chop off a bit more like those that were, say, halfway across the country. I'm not terribly fond of needing more than a few hours in flight to return to my loved ones.

Last but certainly not least, I think I'm a little more in favor of smaller schools. The potential of drowning as a pin in a haystack or missing the chance to meaningfully interact with my teachers is just a LITTLE too intimidating for me to go beyond, really, 25K or so students.

With all that sorting out of the way, I was done- eighteen schools. Earlier, I mentioned how the real fun began, but in reality, I think I'm just getting started. Now that I've established a solid number of schools from a selection of hundreds, I'll need to begin the much longer process of research, touring, and really getting my hands dirty with where I want to go. It'll be a lot of work, but I'm just glad I got the hardest part over with.

Oh, and here's the list if you're curious: Boston University, Carnegie Mellon University, Cornell University, Dartmouth College, Drexel University, George Washington University, Harvard University, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Northwestern University, Princeton University, Rutgers University, Stony Brook University, University at Buffalo, University of Chicago, University of Maryland - Baltimore County, University of Pennsylvania, University of Virginia.

title: Organize, Organize, Organize
snippet: You've got to organize, organize, organize!
content:
Did you get that? No? One more time for the people in the back- organize, organize, organize.

One of the most crucial parts of the college application process is making sure that you have easy access to a plethora of information at any given moment. You will need to continuously reference everything from extracurriculars to family education to financial data as you work your way through several applications, so it’s important to make sure that you have everything you need and where to find it laid out.

Different strategies work better for different people; as you might've come to realize by now, I’m pretty much obsessed with spreadsheets, so just about everything I do for sorting my college data revolves around Google Sheets. I love being able to sort and filter through relevant categories with ease, but I understand this approach might not be for everyone and can come off as a bit overwhelming. You might prefer to get a notebook to write everything and to keep it in a place you’ll remember. It’s understandable if you might have to bounce between mediums to try and find what works best, but once you’ve landed on something, do your best to stick with it.

In terms of what you should actually be writing down, there’s a lot, especially if you’re more involved with extracurriculars. Yet as far as I can tell, there’s really no downside to sorting through the tedium early, so why not get a head start? Courtesy of the College Bound Organizer, here is what I have determined as necessary to record for easy reference and copying:

  • Parent/guardian education history (undergraduate, graduate. What schools? When did they graduate?)
  • High school information (address, counselor and their contact information)
  • Extracurriculars (roles, length, brief description)
  • Community service involvements (responsibilities, length of time, brief description)
  • Jobs (occupation, length of time, brief description)
  • Summer experiences (internships, pre-college prep programs, and anything else of that nature)
  • Sports (teams, length of time, position, stats if applicable, other responsibilities within those sports, brief description)

You don’t need to go too crazy—save the energy for the essays—but storing these basic aspects of your high school career should help tremendously when you go to start filling out your applications.

In addition, I would highly recommend starting two separate emails- one for completing college applications (including FAFSA and other related programs), and one for applying to / receiving scholarships. Use a professional handle- firstnamelastname.college@gmail.com, for example, and begin to get into a habit of checking these emails regularly. All these different emails might seem like a lot of work, but it ensures the most important information is separated from the rest of your inbox. If you’d like, you can also store all your essays, notes, and/or spreadsheets on your college applications account, just so that finding them when needed is relatively straightforward. Make sure you’re keeping track of your logins and passwords across different websites as well!

title: My December ACT Results
snippet: A look at how I did on my first ACT and what's next.
content:
This is definitely… interesting! Let’s talk about it.

First of all, it's probably worth it to get some facts out of the way. Fact #1: This is a good score. An ACT 33 places me at the 98th percentile for all test takers, and would get me solidly above average for test scores in most colleges. Pretty cool, right?

Well, here’s Fact #2: This isn't the score I'd hoped for. After months of studying and more practice tests than I could count, realistically, I’d expected the lowest I could score to be a 34. I’m definitely left a little dejected by the disparities between these results and what my individual sessions appeared to indicate- from my first practice test until now, I’d never scored below a 35 on English, yet consistently struggled with even a 34 for Reading. These differences might appear minute on the surface, but you’ll have to trust me when I say for those aiming above 30+, every point counts. Just to put it in perspective for those less familiar with the test, a jump from 33 to 36 on the ACT is equivalent to a 150 point improvement on the SAT! That’s pretty staggering.

Honestly, I probably shouldn’t have expected to ace the test on the first try. This is the first time I’d ever taken a standardized test like this with these stakes, and 2-3 tests is the average ‘test goal’ rate across both the SAT and the ACT. I can blame a lot of things for my performance. My lack of familiarity? The curve? (Just four wrong questions on Science got me a 31!) What I ate for breakfast that day? It could come down to anything, but the fact remains that I got a 33.

Which begs the question: what's next?

It didn’t actually occur to me before signing up for the December ACT, but a retake is actually out of the question! I just resolved a tricky schedule conflict on the February date last week so I can make a retreat for my church, and the April date coincides with robotics district championships. This means, to my (partial) dismay, my next and likely final shot at improving my score will need to be the March 2025 SAT. It’s not what I would’ve preferred, based on my limited comparisons of the two tests from the summer, but I performed well on the most recent PSAT with minimal studying, so maybe it’ll work out after all. Truly, though, I think that’s going to be it. There are so many other aspects of the college application-LoRs, extracurriculars, and myriad essays-that I don’t think agonizing over testing is going to be worth it for much longer. A 33 is at or above the 50th percentile score for just under half of my schools, so while I’d still feel a little dejected at having to submit it, it’s not going to be the make or break.

In other news, following some further investigation into the true meaning of college prestige, it appears that I’ll probably have to do some list recalibration anyway. More on that in the near future, along with other articles. Thank you to everyone for your patience, and I’m again very appreciative of all of you for taking the time to read and provide feedback. I’ll see you soon for the next one!

Truly hope this doesn't come off as whiny. At the end of the day, a 33 is, truly, a good result, and beyond that initial Man! I'm seriously not going to be sobbing over it. Hopefully the post has sort of been framed by my expectations as outlined in former articles.

title: Remember, it's YOU
snippet: A few things important to remember about YOU.
content:
General Advice
Remember, it's YOU who is about to enter college, or a trade school, or the military, or the workforce, or whatever else in seven, eight, nine months. No matter how much advice you receive from others that you trust and how well-intentioned they are in giving you that advice, they're not the ones about to live through the next four years. It's YOU. This goes both ways- the positive and the negative.
  • The positive: Someone could honestly believe in their heart of hearts that you are DESTINED for a given school. It seems to have the perfect major opportunities, it's a just-right financial fit, it's a small rural location exactly as you asked for. So, sure, maybe it is the best pick for you. At the end of the day, though? It doesn't matter. Why? Because it's YOU. The most irresponsible decision you can make is allowing the trajectory of your life to fall on someone else's shoulders. That's not a condemnation of advice or recommendations, but YOU need to be the one making the final call based on your own informed research. Gut feelings carry a lot of weight too; if you got a really nasty impression of a tour or interview, consider how that might reflect upon the years to come should you attend.
  • The negative: Even when people think they're being sincere, biases can and will come into play. Sometimes, people can't help but act as if they understand perfectly what's best for you. The amount of blank stares, expressions of genuine surprise, and general bewilderment that I've gotten in response to some of my final college application choices still stun me, I won't lie. However, you've got to remember it's YOU. Listen to what others tell you, seriously- again, I'm not trying to knock the idea of someone giving you advice. However, when you've made a commitment to something, taking advantage of all the information you have at your disposal, and someone tells you no, hard no, you have a choice to make. You can either let someone else decide the trajectory of your life for you, or you can understand that your friends, teachers, even family, don't always have your bigger picture in front of them. Remember, it's YOU.
Common-App Specific Advice
Remember, it's YOU who colleges/ need to see, nobody else. This is true for every single aspect of your application, not just the essay even if that's what comes to mind first. The essay is the most important opportunity for you to display your authentic self, but it's far from the only one. If you're not careful, I suspect you could miss out on some big-time opportunities to tell colleges more about yourself than what your achievements can show on paper.
  • Personal Essay / Supplementals: I'll cover this first since it's, again, your best shot at expressing yourself in your application. You cannot afford to waste any space in your essay with anything less than 1000% authenticity and the fullest possible commitment to bringing out the best of YOU and YOUR character. Your family and friends have incredible backstories, I'm sure, but this is not your moment to share them. Every word counts out of those 650 (or even less if you're writing a supplemental), and you need to make sure they do the most possible to show your own character more than anyone else's. I'll have a dedicated college essay piece coming out very soon that goes into this in more detail. A great piece of advice I received was if someone else could turn in your essay and have it still make sense for their application, it's not personalized enough.
  • SAT/ACT Scores: If you're at or above your school's median, submit your test scores. You are doing a disservice to yourself if you are at the very least on par with the school's testing expectations and choose to leave your performance out. You've worked so hard on cramming up to this point- don't skip this part unless it would legitimately hurt the school's impression of you as a student.
  • Activities: You have almost no space at all for these! No extracurricular is too small, broadly speaking, so from the get go you'll want to make sure you're representing the full scope of everything you do outside of school. Then, within the descriptions, be as specific as you can! Don't go 'Worked at a restaurant', go 'developed socialization skills by interacting with hundreds of customers a week at a restaurant'!
